awd_titl_txt: SusChEM: Extending organochromium chemistry - stable alkyl hydrides and high-valent alkylidenes
awd_abstract_narration:
The Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division supports the project by Professor Klaus Theopold.  Professor Theopold is a faculty member in the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry at the University of Delaware.  He is extending the organometallic chemistry of chromium in previously unexplored directions.  One part of this project aims to explore the activation of carbon-hydrogen bonds of simple hydrocarbons.  The activation and functionalization of carbon (C)-hydrogen (H) bonds is a significant challenge and offers opportunities for the synthesis of useful organic molecules.  The other part of this project explores the reactivity of chromium alkylidenes in the highest possible oxidation state (VI) of that metal.  Such molecules are rare and their potential for catalytic transformation were unknown prior to this work. Accordingly, the research project is uncovering new catalytic reaction pathways that aid modern synthetic organic chemistry.  The work lies at the interface of inorganic and organic chemistry. Its broad reach is designed to train synthetic chemists at all levels.  Professor Theopold's outreach activities include service as judge for a high school science fair, volunteer work for the Franklin Institute, a science museum in Philadelphia, PA, and the publication of a textbook for General Chemistry courses for Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics majors. 
 
Previous work in the Theopold laboratory has led to the discovery of several unusually stable dinuclear chromium alkyl hydrides of the type LCr(mu-R)(mu-H)CrL, which may be seen as products of the C-H activation of hydrocarbons, and which in turn engage in C-H activation reactions of simple hydrocarbons. One part of the project is to identify synthetic routes for the preparation and structural characterization of a wider range of such compounds.  This study facilitates an examination of their relative stability and reactivity.  The program also includes investigations of the mechanism of their reaction with hydrocarbons, leading to alkyl group exchange. In another extension of chromium chemistry, a rare chromium alkylidene has been prepared and its structure determined.  This project involves the synthesis of alkylidenes of the type (ArN)2Cr(VI)=CHR.  The reactivity of these unusually high-valent compounds has not previously been explored in any detail.  Potential catalytic applications involve olefin metathesis and polymerization.  The synthetic work is augmented by relevant DFT calculations.  Prof. Theopold's research group is diverse and offers educational opportunities to students underrepresented in science fields and students with disabilities.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The title of this project  was ‘SusChEM: Extending organochromium chemistry - stable alkyl hydrides and high-valent alkylidenes’.  As suggested, there were really two separate lines of investigation, albeit both concerning the organometallic chemistry of chromium, which has been a longstanding focus of our interest. 
   The first subproject was motivated by a fortuitous discovery in our lab - some time ago - that a binuclear alkyl hydride of the constitution LCr(μ-R)(μ-H)CrL (L = β-diketiminate, R = CH2SiMe3) was remarkable stable, even upon prolonged heating.  This observation flew in the face of the general notion that transition metal alkyl hydrides, at least of first row transition metals, are generally unstable with respect to reductive elimination of alkane (RH) for thermodynamic reasons.  Our objective was to find out if this particular molecule was unique, or if other examples could be made and their reactivity be characterized.  We reasoned that molecules of the type LCr(μ-R)(μ-H)CrL could be considered the products of oxidative addition of a simple hydrocarbon (i.e. a ‘C-H activation’) to a low-talent species of the type LCrCrL.  The latter would be interesting for many reasons, including the nature (bond order?) of its metal-metal bond.  Besides, the products of the C-H activation might be subject to further functionalization, and thus provide a pathway for the (catalytic?) functionalization of alkanes, an attractive transformation.
   Accordingly we set out to prepare other examples of these binuclear alkyl hydrides.  An initial synthetic foray, consisting of the reaction of the binuclear hydride LCr(μ-H)2CrL with diazoalkanes (aiming at an insertion of an alkylidene into a metal hydride, to form the alkyl ligand), was not met with success, leading to a wide variety of other products.  Eventually we found that the hydrogenolysis of mononuclear Cr(II) alkyls of the type LCr(THF)R yielded series of binuclear compounds of the type sought.  Another approach was the addition of alkyl lithium reagents to binuclear hydrides of the type L’Cr(μ-H)2CrL’ (L’ = α-diimine).  All of these products proved relatively stable, although with different half-lives.  Importantly, we found that the former could react with other hydrocarbon to give the products of apparent C-H activation.  However, it was found that the reaction mechanism involved a dissociation and subsequent s-bond metathesis of the coordinatively unsaturated alkyl.  In other words, there is no reductive elimination of hydrocarbon, nor its microscopic reverse, namely an oxidative addition.  Our conclusion was that binuclear alkyl hydrides can indeed be very stable and that the 3-center-2-electron bonding involved in their formation changes the thermodynamics of their formation.  The mechanism of their decomposition turned out not to be what he had thought, and that diminished the utility of these compounds for the purpose of hydrocarbon functionalization.  At that point we terminated the investigation.
   The second subproject we pursued concerned the preparation and study of the reactivity of chromium alkylidenes.  We had, over the years, made several attempts to prepare such molecules containing chromium in various intermediate formal oxidation states, but to no avail.   We were intrigued by a report in 1996 of a chromium neopentylidene of hexavalent chromium, namely (ArN)2Cr(=CHCMe3)(L).  This compound had not been structurally characterized and the chemistry seemed abandoned.  An obvious motivation for the pursuit of these molecules is their potential as olefin metathesis catalysts, similar to, but yet different in reactivity and selectivity, to their heavier homologs (containing Mo and W).
   Our first step was to prepare a crystalline derivative of the neopentylidene, namely (ArN)2Cr(=CHCMe3)(PPh3), and determine its molecular structure.  It is indeed a Cr(VI) alkylidene.  We then found that an analogous alkylidene could be prepared containing an SiMe3 substituent at the a-carbon.  Whereas the phosphine stabilized alkylidenes did not react with olefins, we found that 3-coordinate alkylidene intermediates - (ArN)2Cr(=CHCMe3) - did react with olefins to produce metallacyclobutanes.  In other words, both types of intermediates of the catalytic cycle for the olefin metathesis could be obtained, but yet there was no catalytic activity!   We believe that the metallacyclobutane in this system is too stable to allow reversal of the 2+2 cycloaddition.  This is something we wish to test in future work, by modifying the coordination environment of the chromium.
   While investigating the neutral alkylidenes, we also found that Cr(VI) dialkyls are unexpectedly ‘acidic’, suffering deprotonation by KN(SiMe3)2.  This reaction represents an alternative to the α-abstraction, and it yielded a series of anionic alkyl alkylidenes.  Furthermore, we found that the 3-coordinate alkylidene intermediates can add ordinary hydrocarbons across the Cr=C bond.  These organometallic compounds (alkyls and alkylidenes) of chromium inits highest possible oxidation state are very unusual, and we hope to continue their exploration.

   The results of this work have been the subject of three Ph.D. theses and  3 peer-reviewed publications so far.


Last Modified: 11/25/2019
Modified by: Klaus H Theopold
por.por_txt_cntn:
The title of this project  was ‘SusChEM: Extending organochromium chemistry - stable alkyl hydrides and high-valent alkylidenes’.  As suggested, there were really two separate lines of investigation, albeit both concerning the organometallic chemistry of chromium, which has been a longstanding focus of our interest.  
   The first subproject was motivated by a fortuitous discovery in our lab - some time ago - that a binuclear alkyl hydride of the constitution LCr(μ-R)(μ-H)CrL (L = β-diketiminate, R = CH2SiMe3) was remarkable stable, even upon prolonged heating.  This observation flew in the face of the general notion that transition metal alkyl hydrides, at least of first row transition metals, are generally unstable with respect to reductive elimination of alkane (RH) for thermodynamic reasons.  Our objective was to find out if this particular molecule was unique, or if other examples could be made and their reactivity be characterized.  We reasoned that molecules of the type LCr(μ-R)(μ-H)CrL could be considered the products of oxidative addition of a simple hydrocarbon (i.e. a ‘C-H activation’) to a low-talent species of the type LCrCrL.  The latter would be interesting for many reasons, including the nature (bond order?) of its metal-metal bond.  Besides, the products of the C-H activation might be subject to further functionalization, and thus provide a pathway for the (catalytic?) functionalization of alkanes, an attractive transformation.
   Accordingly we set out to prepare other examples of these binuclear alkyl hydrides.  An initial synthetic foray, consisting of the reaction of the binuclear hydride LCr(μ-H)2CrL with diazoalkanes (aiming at an insertion of an alkylidene into a metal hydride, to form the alkyl ligand), was not met with success, leading to a wide variety of other products.  Eventually we found that the hydrogenolysis of mononuclear Cr(II) alkyls of the type LCr(THF)R yielded series of binuclear compounds of the type sought.  Another approach was the addition of alkyl lithium reagents to binuclear hydrides of the type L’Cr(μ-H)2CrL’ (L’ = α-diimine).  All of these products proved relatively stable, although with different half-lives.  Importantly, we found that the former could react with other hydrocarbon to give the products of apparent C-H activation.  However, it was found that the reaction mechanism involved a dissociation and subsequent s-bond metathesis of the coordinatively unsaturated alkyl.  In other words, there is no reductive elimination of hydrocarbon, nor its microscopic reverse, namely an oxidative addition.  Our conclusion was that binuclear alkyl hydrides can indeed be very stable and that the 3-center-2-electron bonding involved in their formation changes the thermodynamics of their formation.  The mechanism of their decomposition turned out not to be what he had thought, and that diminished the utility of these compounds for the purpose of hydrocarbon functionalization.  At that point we terminated the investigation.
   The second subproject we pursued concerned the preparation and study of the reactivity of chromium alkylidenes.  We had, over the years, made several attempts to prepare such molecules containing chromium in various intermediate formal oxidation states, but to no avail.   We were intrigued by a report in 1996 of a chromium neopentylidene of hexavalent chromium, namely (ArN)2Cr(=CHCMe3)(L).  This compound had not been structurally characterized and the chemistry seemed abandoned.  An obvious motivation for the pursuit of these molecules is their potential as olefin metathesis catalysts, similar to, but yet different in reactivity and selectivity, to their heavier homologs (containing Mo and W).
   Our first step was to prepare a crystalline derivative of the neopentylidene, namely (ArN)2Cr(=CHCMe3)(PPh3), and determine its molecular structure.  It is indeed a Cr(VI) alkylidene.  We then found that an analogous alkylidene could be prepared containing an SiMe3 substituent at the a-carbon.  Whereas the phosphine stabilized alkylidenes did not react with olefins, we found that 3-coordinate alkylidene intermediates - (ArN)2Cr(=CHCMe3) - did react with olefins to produce metallacyclobutanes.  In other words, both types of intermediates of the catalytic cycle for the olefin metathesis could be obtained, but yet there was no catalytic activity!   We believe that the metallacyclobutane in this system is too stable to allow reversal of the 2+2 cycloaddition.  This is something we wish to test in future work, by modifying the coordination environment of the chromium.
   While investigating the neutral alkylidenes, we also found that Cr(VI) dialkyls are unexpectedly ‘acidic’, suffering deprotonation by KN(SiMe3)2.  This reaction represents an alternative to the α-abstraction, and it yielded a series of anionic alkyl alkylidenes.  Furthermore, we found that the 3-coordinate alkylidene intermediates can add ordinary hydrocarbons across the Cr=C bond.  These organometallic compounds (alkyls and alkylidenes) of chromium inits highest possible oxidation state are very unusual, and we hope to continue their exploration.

   The results of this work have been the subject of three Ph.D. theses and  3 peer-reviewed publications so far.
